s0: ^Early on a Sunday. Most of Ruritania City is still asleep. Your shabby apartment on Altamont Street hums with the sound of your fridge. You're up early even though it's a weekend and you don't have to get on the train to your job as a yak shaver.

apartment: ^Today's the FinancialiX presale. Some of your friends managed to secure an allocation for yourselves, partially due to luck, partially by paying close attention, and partially by contributing to the FNCLX community. You were dumb, though, and didn't realize that it was ever actually going to take off the way that it did, so you don't have an allocation and instead have to buy in at the main sale. You're hoping for a big win. You just need to make sure your finances are in order, so you can buy in at the main sale, which is first come, first served.

s2: ^A pigeon lands on the fire escape.

b: ^ You're all set to finally log on to The Gate and buy into FinancialiX.

s0: ^FinancialiX is the first defi protocol allowing for under-monitored, over-collateralized, multi-rehypothecated, derivatives on the third derivative of the TVL of all the semi-stablecoin protocols built on polymegaexchange IntelliChain (MIC). It's a really cool project, and you think it's going to be very big, but it got posted on some websites and now it's getting popular. It's only listed on one exchange, The Gate, which is based abroad, in Magonia.
s1: ^You don't need to think about it more, you need to own it.

the_gate_1: ^The Gate's interface is a little clunky, but you've made an account already. You log on. A big readout announces that FinancialiX's presale's going to start in three hours. You've got some time to get things in order.

c-0: ^You've not used The Gate before, usually you're on BestExchange, so you don't have any fiat in it yet. But, you did connect your bank so it looks okay.

deposit: ^How much are you going to bet on FinancialiX? You make a total of 500 florins a month from your job as a yak shaver. You've got 2000 florins in your account at the Bank of Ruritania. A prompt asks you how much you'd like to deposit.

c-0: ^You're not that sure about FinancialiX, but anyways you think that even ten florins of FinancialiX is going to be worth a lot. You've looked at some of the source code, and their turboencabulation engine is something that nobody's ever even attempted before.
^You press enter. An error message pops up:
c-1: ^Maybe you're wrong. Can't hurt to think for a moment.
^You type in 100 florins. Anything less than that would be a missed opportunity. Nobody's done anything before using the third derivative of all the semi-stablecoin protocols.

c-0: ^You press enter. An error message pops up:
c-1: ^Maybe you're wrong. Can't hurt to think for a moment.

c-2: ^You type in 500 florins. You can lose a month of income if this doesn't work out, but you're basically sure that this is going to take off like crazy. How could it not? Everyone wants in on DeFi, and there's never been a better way to do it than multi-rehypothecated logarithmic Gödel springs.

c-0: ^You press enter. An error message pops up:
c-1: ^Maybe you're wrong. Can't hurt to think for a moment.

c-3: ^You type in 2000 florins. You're sure this is going to be the biggest thing. It's going to go to the moon. Nothing in DeFi has come close to this level of panametric delta complexity before.

b: ^ The error still stares at you from the computer screen:

error: ^"ERROR: We're sorry, but your transaction has failed. Please contact your bank's customer support to see if you can resolve this issue, or use a different account."

c-0: ^You shout obscenities and wave your fists in the air. Your neighbor bangs on the wall to try to get you to stop.
^Your shouts make a cacophony, as ugly as the Bank of Ruritania. You're sort of proud of how filthy your obscenities have become.
c-1: ^You stop freaking out. Good. Got to get ahold of yourself.

^You think for a second. You might be able to get through to your bank's customer support to see what the error is back. But, also, there has to be another bank that you can use to get this to work somewhere in this city. Which. You've only got a few hours before FinancialiX goes live. You need to make sure you get at least some of it. You can't pass up this opportunity.

success: ^Wow. It worked. Perfectly. The money's there, in your account. You made it, on time. All you've got to do is press one more button, to buy your FinancialiX.

c-0: ^You press the button, and your life changes forever.

c-1: ^The  knock just keeps coming, and now they've started ringing your doorbell. Someone really wants to talk to you.

c-0: ^You keep waiting. You waste valuable time. Now that you're scared you've stopped making so much noise, and it seems like your neighbor and whoever was at the door have decided to ignore you. The error message stares back at you from the computer.

kristoff: ^It's Kristoff, the building manager. An old fellow with no time for nonsense. A cigarette juts out of his mouth. He's clearly

c-0: ^You apologize. He glares at you, and walks away. You get ahold of yourself, and walk back to the computer.
c-1: ^Kristoff just glares at you, and then, politely, tells you to please stay quiet. He walks off before you can say anything else. Embarrassed, you walk back to the computer.
c-2: ^You open your mouth and get half a syllable out before he cuts you off.
^"Shut your mouth whippersnapper!" Kristoff shouts quietly.

c-0: ^"You idiot. I manage this apartment building. You're not special. It's early. There are other tenants. They are still asleep, or they are enjoying morning quiet. You, on the other hand, seem to be having a mental breakdown."

^You start trying to ask him to be lenient on you, but he doesn't want to hear it. He cuts you off after rolling his eyes, offering one word: "Quiet." He then walks off, leaving you standing in the doorway. You walk back to your computer.
c-1: ^After glaring at you for about thirty seconds, Kristoff offers one word: "Quiet." He then walks off, leaving you standing in the doorway. You walk back to your computer to try and figure out what your next move is.

^You shout back something about how the Bank of Ruritania is trying to ruin your life. He glares at you. "Bank of Ruritania is trying to ruin everyone's life. You are not special. Calm down, or I am calling the police."

b: ^ You try, but you feel sufficiently judged by the building manager that you start hyperventilating. Kristoff starts dialing the cops on his cellphone. You don't even go back in your apartment to wait for them to arrive. After a few minutes, the police arrive, and you spend the next few hours trying to talk them out of charging you with anything. You try again to connect your bank to The Gate again when they finally leave, but the price of FinancialiX is already up by 5000%, and even then the attempt to connect your bank fails. For the rest of your life, you think about what it might have been like to get to buy some FinancialiX.

^ You calm down. Kristoff keeps glaring at you, but he seems appeased for now.  After glaring at you for a minute to see if the calm is going to last, Kristoff offers one word: "Quiet." He then walks off, leaving you standing in the doorway. You walk back to your computer.

c-1: ^You keep shouting at him. He steps back, and starts dialing the cops on his cellphone. b: ^ Your apartment is just as you left it.

orientation: ^No matter what you're going to do, you need more information. How are you going to get it?
^Call the customer service number on the back of your Bank of Ruritania debit card.
^Look for information on if the Bank of Ruritania's policies have changed.
^Text one of your friends for help

c-1: ^A quick search brings up a news article. The headline reads "Bank of Ruritania blocks cryptocurrency exchanges to protect consumers"
^Maybe you know enough from just the headline...
c-2: ^You type "crypto friendly banks in Ruritania" into Googdexbo.
c-3: ^You try to think of anyone who might know. Unfortunately, you can't think of anyone. All of your friends think that cryptocurrencies are silly, and that your interest in them is weird. Or, they're the few friends that already have allocations from working on FinancialiX, and don't have to buy into the public sale and can just hodl. Honestly, one of the reasons you want to win big in crypto is that you want to quit your job, move out of this city, and find better friends.
c-4: ^You put on your shoes and coat, and walk out of the building.

news_article: ^The article isn't very detailed, but it seems like the Republic of Fiatistan, the biggest economy in the world, has pressured international banks to comply with their regulations against cryptocurrency. The chairman of the Bank of Ruritania, Johnny Emerald, commented that he "hopes that one day the world can be ready for cryptocurrency, but that is a matter for tomorrow, not today."
^Seems like you need a new bank if you're going to get any FinancialiX. Can you find one in Ruritania City in time?
^Curse Johnny Emerald and the Bank of Ruritania!

c-0: ^There's really no time. You control the impulse.

The voice just goes on all the way up to fifteen with information you don't need, and then, "To switch to our voice recognition system, please press zero zero. s0: ^There aren't a lot of results on Baigoogdex. The regulations in Ruritania have made it next to impossible for banks to open without having a phyiscal office. At least you live in the capital, so they all have offices here. You've got enough time to get there right as they open at 9AM.

baigoogdex: ^Read an article from Cryptotania, the "premier source for Ruritanian Crypto News"

b: ^You open the Cryptotania article.  The article says that

^ is "working on making crypto available to all Ruritanian Citizens" and is "hoping to create a crypto friendly environment," but it's really noncommittal. You're not sure if it's basically just marketing, or if they'll actually handle the transaction for you. Seems like it might just be marketing. Anyways, they've got a branch near Gasworks Station. You could be there in time for opening on the metro.

altamont_street: ^Altamont street is quiet. The Old City has been pretty dead ever since most business moved to the new office parks and factories in the suburbs. Sometimes there are a few tourists, but not when it's cold like this.

c-1: ^You walk back to your apartment building, up the stairs and into your apartment.

altamont_station: ^The entrance to the metro station is covered in graffiti, and the whole station smells of tobacco and rust.
^Swipe your metro card and descend to the subway platform

c-1: ^Morning commuters stand on the platform, waiting for their trains. Which station are you traveling to?

c-0: ^The train rushes and clanks its way to your destination.
c-1: ^The train rushes and clanks its way to your destination.

gasworks_station: ^Gasworks station takes its name from the massive disused gasworks that has now been converted into a park called Gasworks Square. The metro station entrance is dug into what used to be a small storage building. It's one of the newest stations in the metro system, all shiny and chrome.
^Swipe your metro card and descend to the subway platform

gasworks: ^Gasworks Square sits in the center of what used to be an industrial district full of factories and warehouses. Now, it's a trendy district full of coffee shops, graphic design studios, and used clothing stores. Still, even hipsters need banks, and a couple of banks have branches here.
weaver_street_station: ^Weaver Street station was built back in the 70s, and shows it, all jutting angles, unfinished concrete, and sickly orange coloration.

weaver_street: ^Weaver street was once that, a street where all the weavers of Ruritania City would manufacture cloth and sell it, but now that name is a relic of the past, and it's mostly anonymous offices and small restaurants selling lunch to office workers.
^Walk into the Weaver Street metro station
lowDifficultyBank: ^ doesn't even really look like a bank. It's just a small, storefront office with the name of the bank on its front, next to a coffee shop and a dry cleaners.

c-0: ^A bell attached to the door rings as you walk in.

interior: ^The interior of the branch office is small, but professional. A receptionist sits at a desk, and there are several couches to wait to talk to a representative.

c-0: ^Right as you walk up to her, the phone rings and she picks it up. "Just a minute" she says.
^Sit down on one of the couches to wait.
^Insist to speak with her immediately by telling her that it's an emergency.
^You sit down on one of the couches to wait, overhearing a conversation that seems to never end.
^They're typical for waiting rooms. Celebrity gossip. Health advice. You try to amuse yourself with them for a moment, but you can't stop thinking about FinancialiX.

c-1: ^You tell her it's an emergency. Strangely she seems to respond well to this, politely tells the person on the phone that she'll call them back, and looks at you expectantly.

c-0: ^You walk over to talk to her. She looks up and asks if you need anything more.
^Realize that you don't. You should go home and finish buying into FinancialiX.
^You walk out. The bell rings again as you exit.

receptionist: ^Tell her that you need to open a new checking account immediately but don't say why.
^Tell her that you need to buy FinancialiX

g-0: ^"Oh, that should be fine," she responds. "We get a lot of people here with urgent requests. A lot of the other banks just seem to make everything hard for no good reason. I'll just need to see an ID."
g-1: ^"And you'll be funding this new account with a bank transfer? I'm sorry, we don't do cash deposits. This office is just here for opening and closing accounts, since we do everything else online. This wouldn't be here at all, if not for the regulations. We don't even keep any money here. "
g-2: ^"Alright, just write down your banking details or hand me a debit card, and we can finish getting you set up." The receptionist enters your banking details into a computer on her desk. "Looks like this will be all set up in about an hour. I can make you a temporary debit card here, or I can mail one to you, since I already got your address from your ID." She produces a packet of papers. "Here's everything you might need to get set up for your account online once you get home."

c-4: ^You hand over the debit card and tell her how much you want to move to the account, wait for two minutes, and then she hands it back to you. "All done." You're slightly stunned at how fast this was. You should go home to your apartment on Altamont Street and finish buying FinancialiX as soon as you can.

highDifficultyBank: ^ is glamorous. all metal and glass, new construction in between hundred-year-old buildings that seem to either be abandoned, bought by speculators, or being remodeled, you can't tell which. An ATM is installed on the outside of the building.

b: ^ The security guard that threw you out is staring at you from behind the thick plate glass doors.

c-0: ^The heavy plate glass doors swing weightlessly as you walk inside.
^Why would you put yourself through that again? You already have an account with this nightmare.
^The security guard glares at you and shakes his head, locking the door. You're definitely not getting inside
^ at this point, and you're lucky that you didn't get into more trouble.
^Why would you do that? It's not like you can open accounts from ATMs, and you don't need to pay an exorbitant fee to just take cash out of the Bank of Ruritania.

interior: ^ feels more like an aircraft hanger than a place designed for people. The walls rise, sloped, to the ceiling, and the voices of employees and customers echo around the space. Advertisements for loan paper the walls. A heavily fortified set of teller windows sits on the opposite end of the bank, after a field of furniture that no one is sitting in. A long line of customers wait for their turn to talk to the tellers. There are other bankers in offices to the sides, but there seems to be no way to talk to them other than talking to the tellers first.

b: ^ A security guard stands to the side, surveying everything.

forms: ^Alright, you've got to get through these.

c-0: ^The first form seems to consist only of your name and information that could be found on your national ID card.

^The next form consists of information on your employer, how much money you make, how much you pay in taxes, and various disclosures as to whether you work for the government, other banks, or foreign powers.
^Keep going. This can't take that much longer.

^The last two pages seem to consist entirely of hand writing about twenty different security questions, most of which are so standard and easy to find out about anyone on Baigoogdex as to be useless. It's not hard to find out your mother's maiden name...

^And you're finally done, after signing your name attesting that you won't do business with countries that Ruritania has sanctioned, and writing down the name of your first pet, and your kindergarten teacher.

^You give up, this can't be worth the amount of time it's going to take.

b: ^You finally make it to the teller again, and hand her the forms. She takes one glance at them. "These aren't completely filled out," she says. "Go back and finish, and then talk to me. Next!" With that the next customer walks up and starts talking to her, leaving you standing there awkwardly.

lunar: ^You're still a hodler at heart, but you bought enough FinancialiX early enough that you were able sell some of it at a massive profit; enough to let you buy a house on the moon when the International Moon City managed to get built. You've spent the last few decades working on whatever seemed the most valuable to you at the time, often with other people that you met through the FinancialiX community. $FNCLX has grown into something bigger than anyone expected it to: a global network of like minded people with enough wealth to live according to their values, rather than chasing profit at every turn.

^Now you're waiting in the rocket that's going to take you to your new home at the new Ruritania City Spaceport. Thirty or so other new Lunar citizens sit next to you in their chairs, all ready to immigrate to the moon. One of them smiles at you. You talked to him earlier; it turned out that you'd been interacting with him for the last few decades on the FinancialiX chatrooms, working on a few coding projects that sparked your interest. Everyone is quiet with excitement for the trip. Almost none of them have been off earth before, except the crew who run this trip every few weeks. You look out the window, at the city that you grew up in and spent most of your life in. It's doing better than when you were a kid. The old buildings have been fixed up, and new ones have been built. A new world has come into being. You say goodbye,

bank.#: if bankrandomization is 1, goodbank is at weaver street. If bankrandomization is 2, goodbank is at gasworks
